doc:
Marianne Oswald https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marianne_Oswald 0 Marianne Oswald (January 9, 1901 – February 25, 1985) was the stage name of Sarah Alice Bloch, a French singer and actress born in Sarreguemines in Alsace-Lorraine. She took this stage name from a character she much admired, the unhappy Oswald in the Ibsen play Ghosts. She was noted for her hoarse voice, heavy half-Lorraine, half-German accent, and for singing about unrequited love, despair, sadness, and death. She sang the songs of Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht. She was friends with Jean Cocteau, Jacques Prévert, François Mauriac, and Albert Camus. In fact, the text for one of her album covers was written by Camus. She was an inspiration for the composers Francis Poulenc and Arthur Honegger. Marianne_Oswald ( January_9_,_1901 – February_25_,_1985 ) was the_stage_name of Sarah_Alice_Bloch , a_French_singer_and_actress born in Sarreguemines in Alsace-Lorraine . She took this_stage_name from a_character she much admired , the_unhappy_Oswald in the_Ibsen_play_Ghosts . She was_noted for her_hoarse_voice , heavy_half-Lorraine , half-German_accent , and for singing about unrequited_love , despair , sadness , and death . She sang the_songs of Kurt_Weill and Bertolt_Brecht . She was friends with Jean_Cocteau , Jacques_Prévert , François_Mauriac , and Albert_Camus . In fact , the_text for one of her_album covers was_written by Camus . She was an_inspiration for the_composers_Francis_Poulenc and Arthur_Honegger .
